abstract.para: When deploying the raw or selfinstall images, the system must distinquish the first boot from subsequent boots. This topic covers how is this action performed.

topic.para: The deployment configuration runs on the first boot only. To distinguish between the first and subsequent boots, the flag file /boot/writable/firstboot_happened is created after the first boot finishes. If the file is not present in the file system, the attribute ignition.firstboot is passed to the kernel command line and thus both &ignition; and &combustion; are triggered to run (in the initrd). After completing the first boot, the /boot/writable/firstboot_happened flag file is created.

note.title: The flag file is always created
note.para: Even though the configuration may not be successful because of improper or missing configuration files, the /boot/writable/firstboot_happened flag file is created.

section.title: Force system reconfiguration on a subsequent boot
section.para: If you need to reconfigure your system after the first boot happened, you can force the reconfiguration on the subsequent boot. Here you have two options.

listitem.para: You can pass the ignition.firstboot=1 attribute to the kernel command line.
You can delete the flag file /boot/writable/firstboot_happened.
